abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            reducing poverty and improving the quality of life in
            agrarian reform communities in Philippines. In 2002, about
            37 percent of the rural population in the Philippines lived
            below the poverty line. An integral part of the
            government's strategy for reducing poverty and inequity
            in land ownership, particularly in rural areas, had been the
            land reform program implemented through the Comprehensive
            Agrarian Reform Program. The project funded by World Bank
            implemented community development and capacity-building
            activities to ensure active community participation and
            self-reliance among agrarian reform beneficiaries and
            organizations. Using a community-driven approach, rural
            infrastructure was provided based on the prioritized needs
            of the communities. It included rural roads, bridges,
            small-scale irrigation, potable water supply systems and
            post-harvest facilities. Through the assistance of the World
            Bank, the Philippines boosted agricultural and enterprise
            productivity by at least 17 percent over the life of the
            project and had increased the household incomes of
            smallholder farmers and their families by about 21 percent
            in 124 communities by improving their access to agriculture
            and related support services.
